comments.video_title: The Most Underrated Muscle for Looking Jacked (And How to Build It)
comments.text:
Good stuff, appreciate your videos! However I don't think the wrist roller trains the opposite muscles (wrist extension in your example) on the way down, since your resistance is still in the same direction; the only difference is that on the way down it's resisting the weight falling down instead of bringing it up. It's just like the eccentric of a push up, which doesn't make it a pull exercise; it still uses the same muscles as the concentric. To turn the wrist roller into a wrist extension exercise you have to turn it around, so that the band hangs from the other side of the bar. Right?

I also like to train wrist radial and ulnar deviation (with a stick with weight on one end) as well as wrist pronation and supination (with something like a judo belt with weight plates hanging from it) and dumbbell finger rolls. As a climber I feel like this could help a lot in injury prevention.
comments.author: @kewner8556

comments.text:
You know what the worst part of this is?
You are correct.

Ive been training and checking what i eat for about more than a month now. Before that i started walking and some cardio.
Im slowly getting stronger and slowly lose fat but also gain muscle.
Can do a full set of pushups now and probably can do my first pullup soon too.
This was impossible for me before i started. I didnt exercise at all.

Consistency just works, but it is slow. And if things slow down, i probably only need to change something small and continue.
You know what sucks most about this? There is no magic. 

No special thing that makes this faster (without extreme drawbacks).
No "hack" that makes it easier.
No Supplement that makes this effortless.

There is no shortcut. "Keep it simple stupid". 
From my experience, which isnt too much yet but still,
start with something. Even "just" walking will do a lot for you. And then slowly add more to it over time.

comments.video_title: Is Your Workout Actually Enough to Build Muscle?
comments.text:
I started training in 1978 when I was 14. Two years before that, I threw out my back shanking a punt during football—ended up with spondylolisthesis in my L5-S1. Doctors told me not to lift, said it would make it worse. My back was so unreliable I’d often sit out gym class, until an 8th grade teacher warned me I wouldn’t get away with that in high school.

Everything changed when my youth football coach’s son took me down to their basement and showed me his barbell set. I tried a bench press, then a curl—95 lbs. on each, sloppy as hell, but I got them up. I was hooked. Got my own barbell set the following Christmas.

My goal wasn’t to get big—it was to get strong. All I had to go by was the wall chart that came with my 110 lb. Diversified Products set from Sears (where my dad worked) -- cement inside with a plastic coating.  I followed it religiously. And I got strong—even more once I got an adjustable bench w/leg extension the next year.

But something else happened. I hit my growth spurt hard. Between freshman and sophomore year, I went from 108 lbs. to 162 lbs. People noticed. Friends asked about my bench, teachers told me I looked good. That’s when I got serious—books, a chin-up bar in my doorway,  learning about diet. The muscle came as a byproduct of getting stronger.

I never looked back. Never had interest in stepping on a bodybuilding stage—not even once. But I did turn it into a career as a pro wrestler. That strength paid off in other ways too, like working as a land surveyor and being able to remove 230 lb. manhole covers by myself, one-handed.

Eventually, you realize you can only grow so much. The rest of the journey is about holding onto what you’ve built—and fighting like hell not to lose it.
comments.author: @firebird7479

comments.text:
I agree. I decided to change my workout plan based on the time I have available.

Upper Day 1(Chest and Back Focused): 3 Back Exercises(3 sets each), 2 chest exercises(3 sets each), 1 bicep(2 sets) and 1 tricep(2 sets) exercise. Max Time taken 45-50 Minutes.

Legs + Shoulders 1: 2 Quad Movements, 3 shoulder movements, 1 hamstring movement and 1 calf movement+3 Sets of Hammer Curls(50 Minutes to 1 hour depending on my rest time)

Rest Day

Upper Day 2(Bicep and Tricep focused): 2 Biceps Exercises(3 sets each), 2 triceps exercises(3 sets each), 1 chest exercise(2 sets), 2 back exercises(2 sets)(45-50 Minutes total again)

Legs+Shoulders 2: Same as the first one.

4 days a week with 3 rest days. Have been managing extremely well and it doesn't feel like I'm missing out. High Intensity too.

What is your personal opinion on this?

comments.video_title: I’ve Done 1,500 Workouts. This One Thing Matters Most For Getting Jacked
comments.text:
Intuitive training is good; it depends on your experience. You can always progress, especially if you train to failure. If your sets are hard enough, you don’t need to track every weight, but noting your main lifts once a month is a good way to check if you’re truly progressing.

Muscles don’t see numbers—they respond to hard work and progressive overload. Tracking can make linear progression easier, but if you push all sets to failure, your body will naturally adapt and you’ll increase weight intuitively over time.

Bad intuitive training is what you described in the video: training comfortably, constantly changing exercises, chasing pump. That leads to minimal gains.

Good intuitive training, on the other hand, is hard, structured, and consistent. If you listen to your body, train hard, and track main lifts occasionally, you don’t need to log every set.

Tracking everything can be useful, especially for beginners, but the key is finding the right approach for yourself. Some people thrive on high volume, some on lower volume. Some succeed purely intuitively, others with detailed tracking. There is no universal optimal method.

Training smart and hard is the universal key to your dream body.

I’d love to hear your opinion on this because I’m always learning and could be wrong. Love your channel—it helps people stop wasting time in the gym and start training really hard instead of just long.

Take care, brother!
comments.author: @AdmandGaming

comments.video_title: I’ve Done 1,500 Workouts. This One Thing Matters Most For Getting Jacked
comments.text: A common problem in assessing progress is switching around the workouts so often that it becomes impossible to know whether or not you're getting stronger. And make no mistake, STRENGTH is the goal. Judging progress based on body weight will only incentivize weight gain. But the rate of muscle growth is too slow to be useful here. If you are getting measurably stronger on each workout (or nearly so), then muscle growth WILL follow. Now, once you're focused on getting more reps with more weight, then a second common problem arises. You must perform the same exercises for an extend period as mentioned previously, but YOU ALSO MUST maintain the same form and rep cadence. If you are going slow, smooth, and strict one week, but you up the weight and start slinging the weight to get your reps, then are you getting stronger? PROBABLY NOT. You have to keep all the parameters constant in order to assess progress. The only things that should change are the # reps and resistance used. This is how you KNOW you are making progress. "The first principle is that you must not fool yourself - and you are the easiest person to fool." Richard Feynman
comments.author: @MarcosBuenijo1973

comments.video_title: Do This Warm-Up Before Every Workout
comments.text:
48 years of training and I do none of this -- except hang on a chin bar and light stretching of the pecs, shoulders and lats. I jump right in to my heaviest set. Then knock off 10% each subsequent set. Example: This morning I walked into the gym at 7:50 AM, hung from the chin bar for 30 seconds, did my pre-workout stretch, then went for my first set of seated cable rows: 210 lbs. for 7 reps, then 190 for 8 reps on the second set; 170 for 9 reps on the third set. Heavy to light gets your heaviest weight when the muscle is fresh, making the lighter poundages harder in the sets after. 

Walking on a treadmill or a stair stepper has never worked for me as a warm-up.  I do that separately, as well as stretch post-workout which includes band work. I get my mind ready in the shower and on the way to the gym. This works for me.

As Vince Gironda said, "Your first set is your warmup set." There are no such things as "warm up sets", "ramping sets" or "work sets". That's gimmickry and "bro science". I hate that phrase.  EVERY SET YOU DO IS A WORK SET.
comments.author: @firebird7479

They're selling you vegan water as well but nobody sane is gonna pretend like they're part of some vegan movement. Listening to nutritionists giving you average numbers for the general population is also wrong because they're giving you numbers for sustaining a healthy life with some light to moderate fitness like 2 runs a week.
